You probably love Prada, Louis Vuitton, and Chanel replica designer purses but have you learnt how those famous artists became the leaders inside fashion industry. Knowing a little bit about the backgrounds of these design houses can make these purses much more valuable to you.

Prada: A protracted History in Handbags

Back 1913, Mario Prada established the Fratelli Prada retail store in Milan, Italy which often sold leather items, which include handbags. Shockingly, he never approved of doing business interactions with women so the majority his clients were noblemen from through the entire country. Mario died inside 1950's and his daughter-in-law ran the firm for the next twenty years. However it was Mario's daughter Miuccia and her accomplice Patrizio Bertelli took on the company in 1978. Under her, the Prada name started to emerge among the great replica designer labels in the world. While Prada had been with us for more than eight decades, the name arrived to its own in the 1990's and began to become the ultimate trend symbol we've all come to love.

A considerable ways from Luggage: Louis Vuitton

Long before Louis Vuitton was synonymous with an array of beautiful purses available, it was the name of a French man who thought to walk from Jura to help Paris in 1835. The journey was longer but Vuitton was determined to reach your goals. Soon after reaching the city of Lights, he began creating his own luggage and that luggage will be your foundation of his achievements. In 1892, Vuitton's son took in the family business. He brought the name to the united states just a year later by having an exhibition at the Chi town World's Fair. During the first half of the twentieth century, the company started diversifying consequently added handbags, wallets, and purses to its line up of items. However, what really set the stage for any company's success with the women of the world was product placement. In the movie Charade, Audrey Hepburn is filmed carrying a Louis Vuitton replica designer bag. The rest is historical past.
